unicode.value: Objectives describe the expected outcomes of the learning and should define what the learners will be able to do when they have completed the learning tasks.
Type the learning objectives for this resource.
In this real quick course, we're going to learn about different network types.
Provide relevant feedback on the situation.

A case study is a device that provides learners with a simulation that has an educational basis. It takes a situation, generally based in reality, and asks learners to demonstrate or describe what action they would take to complete a task or resolve a situation. The case study allows learners apply their own knowledge and experience to completing the tasks assigned. when designing a case study consider the following:
  • What educational points are conveyed in the story
  • What preparation will the learners need to do prior to working on the case study
  • Where the case study fits into the rest of the course
  • How the learners will interact with the materials and each other e.g. if run in a classroom situation can teams be setup to work on different aspects of the case and if so how are ideas feed back to the class
Describe the activity tasks relevant to the case story provided. These could be in the form of questions or instructions for activity which may lead the learner to resolving a dilemma presented.

Create the case story. A good case is one that describes a controversy or sets the scene by describing the characters involved and the situation. It should also allow for some action to be taken in order to gain resolution of the situation.

Create the case story. A good case is one that describes a controversy or sets the scene by describing the characters involved and the situation. It should also allow for some action to be taken in order to gain resolution of the situation.

Logging onto an employer provided computer might seem different from logging onto your own computer at home - and that's because there may well be a network involved.

If there is - this section wil look at how networks work, and what some of the gotchas that can occur within these network types.

Single Computer

In this scenario there is a single computer in use within the company. Individual users can have their own accounts on the computer

Workgroup

As the workforce increases, then the company might need to buy additional computers - but providing each computer with a printer (for example) can prove expensive, so in this scenario, a resource can be shared within the workgroup.

A PC on this network can share its resources to other machines on the network - so other users can all print to the same printer. Modern printing devices can provide that network sharing without the need for a machine within the workgroup to share a resource. Where a device is being shared by a workgroup computer, it is worth noting that if that machine is switched off, then that resource is no longer accessible to the other machines in the workgroup.

Domain

The biggest issue with the Workgroup model is that the user accounts are stored on each machine.  If you need to use a different machine, then you will need an account on that machine, and that is a job for an Administrator to set up that account with appropriate security.

The Domain model instead allows the company to register each machine that it operates, and store the account passwords centrally.

Adding a new user can now be done centrally, and that user can now log onto any machine that the company manages within it's domain.

So when a company first starts out - as a sole trader - then it might be that a company has a single computer, and as there is only 1 person in the company there is no need for a network.

Windows 10 support the concept of multiple users, so it is possible to log into a windows 10 device using a separate username and password for each user.

Each user on that machine will have their own documents folder, and desktop.  Files placed into those folders will only be accessible to those users.

Logging in

Ctrl + c

+ Tab

As part of an onboarding or induction process, you should be presented with username and password.  The machine you have been allocated should already be on the network.

Most companies- when setting up  new user - set a special flag, that the user must change their password when they next log in.  Be prepared for the possibility that you will need to change your password.

If windows does not prompt you to change your password it is a good idea to change it anyway.

Once logged in,

  • press Ctrl + Alt + Del to bring up a blue menu screen
  • Select Change Password
  • Enter your current password into the Old password box
  • Enter the new password into the New Password box
  • Enter the new password into the Confirm Password 
  • Click "go"....  stuff happens and your password is changed.

Once you are connected to a network, then some resources might be mapped for you automatically.  If your network is a domain based network, then it is possible that your network administrator has set up some login scripts.  These are scripts that are executed when you log into the network, and may well do things like map your drives and attach your printers.

Windows uses letters to refer to drives within your computer - you can see this in Windows Explorer.  By Convention, Windows uses drive letter C onwards to represent drives - so your hard drive is probably drive C.  If you have a CD or DVD ROM then it may be drive D.

Windows Explorer will also allow you to map a network share to a drive letter.
Your employer will have a set of security guidelines - and you should follow those.  But these hints here might also be useful.
Locking your computer when you're not there

Locking your computer is a simple way of restricting access to your machine while you're not at your desk.  You can press Ctrl + Alt + Del to access the Windows Blue Screen, and from there press "Lock"... or

+ l will lock it for you straight away

Store your documents in a suitable location.  It might be that your company has a network share, or even a collaborative tool like SharePoint.  Uses these where possible, to store company documents.  These have the advantage that they should be backed up as part of the network backups, and in the event that your machine has a hardware failure, you should be able to switch to any machine to continue working.

If you're using a computer as part of your job, then it's pretty much a given that you will be sending email.  In this section we'll be talking through how email works, what we can do with it, and some of the pitfalls when using email that we need to consider.
